auto_merge.commit_message:
Use an atomic flag indicating the initialized-status. If in the
intermediate "initializing" state then be lock-free and operate on a
non-shared version instead.

On non-freethreading versions, handle the edge-case where another thread
manages to initialize it while we're working (and so a reference count
is lost).

Switch to vectorcall.

Fixes #6666

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Use an atomic flag indicating the initialized-status. If in the intermediate "initializing" state then be lock-free and operate on a non-shared version instead.

On non-freethreading versions, handle the edge-case where another thread manages to initialize it while we're working (and so a reference count is lost).

Switch to vectorcall.

Fixes #6666

comment_data.body: This style is high limit for a C macro, but an inline function should really use separate if-statements (or even `switch(cfunc->flag)`) to make it clearer what the conditions are and what happens here.

https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/call.html#the-vectorcall-protocol

> `args` is a C array consisting of the positional arguments followed by the values of the keyword arguments. This can be `NULL` if there are no arguments.
I think this was a conscious effort not to change it too much. But I've unpicked it now.

Hmm. This `&EMPTY(tuple)` is a bit of a hack. We basically use the address of a constant `PyObject *` as a zero-sized array. It was difficult to spell this out in a comment when we used a C macro, but now with an inline function, it's at least worth an explanation (if not a cleanup). Really, any pointer would do, including `&self`, but that would still require a code comment.

BTW, given the relevance of the vectorcall protocol these days, I wonder if it's worth passing an array that prepends space for the self-argument. I'm aware that we're calling an unbound method here, and don't expect anything that wants to prepend `self`, but I wonder if there are cases where this still gets forwarded to an actual (bound) method call internally.

So, use `PyObject * args[1] = {0};` instead and set the "self may be added" bit? Just in case? It shouldn't hurt, really, and seems the "obvious way of spelling this".

I think the only concern is that anything but a blunt `&EMPTY(tuple)` would want to put something on the C call stack here
I pushed a comment for now.

The auto-merge triggered pretty much as you posted it. So it can't be fixed as part of this this PR.

My impression is that `NULL` would also be OK although.

> My impression is that `NULL` would also be OK although.

Right. I think I remember that `NULL` wasn't always working when we first experimented with this, but it should be fine now, given that it's even documented. I'll change it to use `NULL`, that's much more obvious.

commit.message:
Make CachedCFunction mechanism thread-safe

Use an atomic flag indicating "initialized" and a PyMutex which
is only held while it's actively being initialized.

On non-freethreading versions, handle the edge-case where
another thread manages to initialize it while we're working
(and so a reference count is lost).

Switch to vectorcall
cover even more unlikely corner case

milestone.description:
* Remove code for Python 2 and Python < 3.8.
* Integrate better with Python 3.
* Improve support for the Limited API.
* Start supporting GIL-free Python 3.13.
* Support the Py3.13 `sys.monitoring` API.
* Support and use `am_send` for coroutines.

title: Make CachedCFunction mechanism thread-safe
